DOC.HEAD: Department Admits Shortcomings In Legal Work On Noriega
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department acknowledged Friday it was in such a rush to indict Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on drug charges that it may not have followed its own rules for making sure state secrets would not be disclosed in court. However, said department spokesman David Runkel, ``We believe there is a strong case against General Noreiga and that case can be successfully brought to trial.'' Some legal experts have said there could be problems in trying Noriega because he would seek to use classified information stemming from his past cooperation with the Central Intelligence Agency. Runkel said on Tuesday that such concerns ``have been grossly exaggerated.'' At a press briefing on Friday, he told reporters that the department may not have followed its usual policy of reviewing, in drawing up an indictment, any classified documents that might be used in a trial. ``I had been informed that that was the policy that had in fact been followed in this case,'' he told reporters. ``It now appears that there was some rush to draw up the Noriega indictment and those guidelines may not have been completely followed,'' he said. Runkel declined to elaborate on the nature of the ``rush'' and said, ``I haven't determined the reason'' for it. He said the department's decision to review the national security issues was an outgrowth of a Dec. 14 meeting of prosecutors in the case with representatives of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Federal Bureau of Investigation and CIA. That meeting was called to discuss drug indictments against Noriega in Miami and Tampa, Fla., and a decision was made to proceed with the Miami case, Runkel said. Noriega reportedly worked closely with the CIA and the Pentagon while he served as the head of Panama's military intelligence service and after he became commander in chief in 1983.
